Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spectrum Efficient Waveform Design with Application to Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Spectrum efficiency refers to the information rate that can be transmitted over a given bandwidth in a specific communication system. It is a measure of how efficiently a limited frequency spectrum is utilized. In this project, innovative spectrum efficient waveform designs are studied towards narrower mainlobe and lower sidelobe in spectrum. It has been recognized that judicious use of properly designed waveforms, coupled with advanced receiver strategies, is fundamental to fully utilizing the capacity of the electromagnetic spectrum. This project seeks innovative approaches on nested and co-prime samplers for spectrum efficiency, and subsequently applies it to wireless networks. Different waveforms designs and diversities are studied based on nested and co-prime samplers. Co-prime samplers are used for Multi-Input Multi-Output communication system. In the application to spectrum efficient wireless networks, nodes exchange information over a common wireless channel. Under different traffic scenarios and different constraints, e.g., bandwidth and signal to noise and interference ratio, the amount of data exchanged among these nodes may vary. A key question then is how the throughput capacity of wireless network improves with the new waveform design schemes and different network setup and how it grows with the number of nodes in the network. This project seeks to help reach the nation's broadband goals and the larger objective of alleviating growing pressure on limited spectrum resources. This project will attract minority and woman students to participate in the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates spectrum-efficient waveform designs for efficient and secure transmissions of a large amount of data within a given wireless bandwidth to meet the needs of applications such as health-care mobile monitoring. Described below are the major outcomes:

  1. Nested sparse sampling and coprime sampling can support secure transmissions of big data. When the sampling spacing is large, the mainlobe of Power Spectral Density (PSD) becomes much narrower than the original Binary Frequency-Shift Keying (BFSK) signals, and so the time consumption is smaller and the occupied bandwidth is also smaller. When the sampling spacing pairs are sufficiently large, the spectrum of BFSK signal performs like Frequency Hopping (FH). With the same multitone interfering signal added to FH/BFSK, the error probability becomes much smaller using nested sampling and coprime sampling compared to the original FH/BFSK signal. Thus, both nested sampling and coprime sampling could be used in Big Data transmission to resist interference, while guaranteeing the transmission performance.
  2. Using the relationship between automatically extracted behavioral characteristics derived from rich smartphone data and Big-Five personality traits, service providers could estimate each user’s probability based on each personality trait using diagnostic inference, and then based on predictive inference to calculate each user’s usage of bandwidth using Bayesian Network. This helps the service provider better allocate smartphone bandwidth, resulting in a smart and efficient usage of the limited bandwidth.
  3. Time-critical Location Based Service (LBS) applications in mobile ad hoc networks require fast localization. The conventional localization techniques are unsuitable for such applications, for they neglect the time needed for localization. As a result, time-critical information may become obsolete. The notion of On-Demand Fast Localization (ODFL) is formulated and a framework is devised to implement this concept over existing routing protocols in MANETs. Analytical and simulation results demonstrate that ODFL can significantly reduce the time solely needed for localization before starting time-critical applications. ODFL can also improve location privacy and reduce energy consumptions.
  4. A system called U-Fall is devised and implemented to detect human falls using the fog computing paradigm including distributed analytics and edge intelligence. The fog computing paradigm splits the detection task between the edge devices (e.g., smartphones attached to the user) and the server (e.g., servers in the cloud). In U-Fall, the detection task is carefully split between the smartphone and the server. While the front-end mobile device quickly conducts lightweight computation for fall detection, the sensor data are also transmitted to the back-end server in real-time for more accurate detection. The front-end and the back-end run our newly devised detection algorithms. This two-stage detection significantly improves the detection results while maintaining a low response time and consuming as little battery power as possible on a smartphone.
